comments.body:
I think I'd rather see this named `placement`. And then `podschedulers` renamed `algorithms`. So the package structure becomes:
- scheduler/components/placement
- scheduler/components/placement/algorithms

I don't like another word for "scheduler" which "placement" would actually be. This is the core algorithm of the whole toplevel module. Introducing "placement" just to avoid the word "scheduler" gives more confusion than making things clearer.
It's confusing for me to see "scheduler" used everywhere. I'd like to be able to see more easily where the line is between the mesos stuff and the kubernetes stuff.
I get your point. I only think that placement is not a good word, especially because this is the core algorithm of the whole package.
I somehow dislike the term placement. It sounds so much like an under-statement.

Also we will turn podscheduler into something more clever in not too far future. Think about the 50000 pod example in 2 minutes, in analogy to Verizon with Marathon. This will require a new algorithm architecture. I would rather not concentrate too much on the current podschedulers.

what about planner?

I think I'd rather see this renamed `registry` of type `Registry`:

``` go
type Registry interface {
    sync.Locker // synchronize changes to tasks
    Tasks() podtask.Registry         
    Offers() offers.Registry
}
```
Don't understand. What do you want to rename?!
instead of the `sched` field, make it a `registry` field. and declare the above Registry type in the same file. limits the scope of the field to what this component actually needs to use.
Don't see the use of more structural complexity here. We have this kind of sched pointer everywhere in the components. The Scheduler interface is meant to be minimal for the whole scheduler.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +37,41 @@// SchedulerAlgorithm implements the algorithm.ScheduleAlgorithm interface
type schedulerAlgorithm struct {
	sched        scheduler.Scheduler
	podUpdates   queue.FIFO
	podScheduler podschedulers.PodScheduler

comments.body: It's not a PodPlacement, it is a Scheduling algorithm. The former will confuse things.
